Sentence 1: Altri scrittori hanno notato somiglianze delle uova alla scozzese con un piatto della cucina Mughlai con carne e uova sode chiamato nargisi kofta ("polpette di Narciso") e un piatto algerino.La prima ricetta stampata delle scotch egg appare nell'edizione del 1809 di A New System of Domestic Cookery di Maria Rundell che, così come altri autori del diciannovesimo secolo, li serviva caldi con la salsa gravy.Oggi le uova alla scozzese sono divenute uno spuntino comune nel Regno Unito, dove vengono vendute in molti negozi e supermercati in diverse varianti e dove vengono servite in molti pub.
Sentence 2: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: A Scotch egg is a boiled egg wrapped in sausage meat, coated in breadcrumbs and baked or deep-fried.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2:
== Origin ==
Various origin stories exist.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: The Oxford Companion to Food gives the first instance of the name as of 1809, in an edition of Maria Rundell's A New System of Domestic Cookery.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: They did not, at that time, have a breadcrumb layer, although by 1861 Isabella Beeton suggested this as an option.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: According to the Oxford Companion to Food, food historian Annette Hope speculated in 1987 that the inspiration may have been Indian koftas such as the Mughlai dish called nargisi kofta ("Narcissus meatballs"), in which a boiled egg is encased in a seasoned ground-meat mixture and then fried.Other claims include the item having been invented at Fortnums.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: According to Culinary Delights of Yorkshire, they originated in Whitby, Yorkshire, England, in the 19th century, and were originally covered in fish paste rather than sausage meat.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: They were supposedly named after William J. Scott & Sons, a well-known eatery which sold them.It has also been suggested that they were originally called "scorch" eggs, as they were cooked over an open flame, though according to surviving recipes they were deep-fried in lard.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: 'Scotching' as a culinary process is also sometimes cited as the origin, though what 'scotching' was is open to interpretation, from the inclusion of anchovies to simply mincing meat.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: Further confusion is added by the large trade in eggs from Scotland in the 19th century, which sometimes involved dipping eggs in a lime powder to preserve them, a process possibly also known as 'scotching'.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2:
== Preparation and serving ==
Scotch eggs are prepared by hard- or soft-boiling an egg, wrapping it in sausage meat, and deep-frying it.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: It is often eaten in pubs or as a cold snack at picnics.In the Netherlands and Belgium, Scotch eggs may also be called vogelnestje ("little bird's nest"), because they contain an egg.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: One 1880s Scottish recipe also calls them birds' nests.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2:
== Regional variation ==
The Manchester egg consists of a pickled egg wrapped in a mixture of pork meat and Lancashire black pudding.Vegetarian versions have also been made.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: In 2022, Guinness World Records certified a 18.341 kilograms (40.43 lb) vegetarian scotch egg as the world's largest.

Sentence 1: Le uova alla scozzese (in inglese scotch egg o egg ball) sono un piatto inglese, spesso consumato come antipasto.
Sentence 2: The Harwood Arms, a Michelin-starred restaurant in London, started selling a vegetarian scotch egg that uses a plant-based meat alternative in 2020, and the next year, the supermarket chain Tesco started selling a vegan version.

Sentence 2:
== Nutrition ==
A fatty food, a typical sausage-coated Scotch egg has about 200 mg dietary cholesterol per 100 grams.

Sentence 1: Consistono in uova sode di gallina o di quaglia che, dopo essere state avvolte con carne tritata di maiale, vengono successivamente rivestite di pangrattato prima di venire cotte o fritte.
Sentence 2: Further confusion is added by the large trade in eggs from Scotland in the 19th century, which sometimes involved dipping eggs in a lime powder to preserve them, a process possibly also known as 'scotching'.

== Preparation and serving ==
Scotch eggs are prepared by hard- or soft-boiling an egg, wrapping it in sausage meat, and deep-frying it.

The Manchester egg consists of a pickled egg wrapped in a mixture of pork meat and Lancashire black pudding.Vegetarian versions have also been made.

Sentence 1: Altri scrittori hanno notato somiglianze delle uova alla scozzese con un piatto della cucina Mughlai con carne e uova sode chiamato nargisi kofta ("polpette di Narciso") e un piatto algerino.La prima ricetta stampata delle scotch egg appare nell'edizione del 1809 di A New System of Domestic Cookery di Maria Rundell che, così come altri autori del diciannovesimo secolo, li serviva caldi con la salsa gravy.Oggi le uova alla scozzese sono divenute uno spuntino comune nel Regno Unito, dove vengono vendute in molti negozi e supermercati in diverse varianti e dove vengono servite in molti pub.

Sentence 1: Consistono in uova sode di gallina o di quaglia che, dopo essere state avvolte con carne tritata di maiale, vengono successivamente rivestite di pangrattato prima di venire cotte o fritte.
Sentence 2: El Huevo a la escocesa (en inglés: Scotch egg) consiste en un plato en el que se sirve frío un huevo duro al que se le ha quitado la cáscara y se le ha recubierto en una mezcla de salchichas picadas finamente, recubierto de pan rallado, y puesto a freír.

Sentence 2: El plato fue inventado en la tienda londinense Fortnum & Mason, en el año 1738.

Sentence 1: Sebbene si pensi che siano state inventate nel grande magazzino londinese di Fortnum & Mason nel 1738, il Culinary Delights of Yorkshire (1981) di Peter Bone afferma che sarebbero nate a Whitby, nello Yorkshire, durante il XIX secolo, e che fossero originariamente ricoperte di pasta di pesce piuttosto che di carne di salsiccia.

Sentence 2: El plato fue inventado en la tienda londinense Fortnum & Mason, en el año 1738.

Sentence 1: Altri scrittori hanno notato somiglianze delle uova alla scozzese con un piatto della cucina Mughlai con carne e uova sode chiamato nargisi kofta ("polpette di Narciso") e un piatto algerino.La prima ricetta stampata delle scotch egg appare nell'edizione del 1809 di A New System of Domestic Cookery di Maria Rundell che, così come altri autori del diciannovesimo secolo, li serviva caldi con la salsa gravy.Oggi le uova alla scozzese sono divenute uno spuntino comune nel Regno Unito, dove vengono vendute in molti negozi e supermercati in diverse varianti e dove vengono servite in molti pub.

Sentence 2: Los huevos a la escocesa se suelen servir fríos, acompañando por regla general a una ensalada y relish.

Sentence 1: Sebbene si pensi che siano state inventate nel grande magazzino londinese di Fortnum & Mason nel 1738, il Culinary Delights of Yorkshire (1981) di Peter Bone afferma che sarebbero nate a Whitby, nello Yorkshire, durante il XIX secolo, e che fossero originariamente ricoperte di pasta di pesce piuttosto che di carne di salsiccia.

Sentence 2: On le mange, chaud ou froid, notamment au cours d'un pique-nique.

Sentence 1: Altri scrittori hanno notato somiglianze delle uova alla scozzese con un piatto della cucina Mughlai con carne e uova sode chiamato nargisi kofta ("polpette di Narciso") e un piatto algerino.La prima ricetta stampata delle scotch egg appare nell'edizione del 1809 di A New System of Domestic Cookery di Maria Rundell che, così come altri autori del diciannovesimo secolo, li serviva caldi con la salsa gravy.Oggi le uova alla scozzese sono divenute uno spuntino comune nel Regno Unito, dove vengono vendute in molti negozi e supermercati in diverse varianti e dove vengono servite in molti pub.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: A Scotch egg is a boiled egg wrapped in sausage meat, coated in breadcrumbs and baked or deep-fried.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2:
== Origin ==
Various origin stories exist.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: The Oxford Companion to Food gives the first instance of the name as of 1809, in an edition of Maria Rundell's A New System of Domestic Cookery.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: They did not, at that time, have a breadcrumb layer, although by 1861 Isabella Beeton suggested this as an option.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: According to the Oxford Companion to Food, food historian Annette Hope speculated in 1987 that the inspiration may have been Indian koftas such as the Mughlai dish called nargisi kofta ("Narcissus meatballs"), in which a boiled egg is encased in a seasoned ground-meat mixture and then fried.Other claims include the item having been invented at Fortnums.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: According to Culinary Delights of Yorkshire, they originated in Whitby, Yorkshire, England, in the 19th century, and were originally covered in fish paste rather than sausage meat.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: They were supposedly named after William J. Scott & Sons, a well-known eatery which sold them.It has also been suggested that they were originally called "scorch" eggs, as they were cooked over an open flame, though according to surviving recipes they were deep-fried in lard.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: 'Scotching' as a culinary process is also sometimes cited as the origin, though what 'scotching' was is open to interpretation, from the inclusion of anchovies to simply mincing meat.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: Further confusion is added by the large trade in eggs from Scotland in the 19th century, which sometimes involved dipping eggs in a lime powder to preserve them, a process possibly also known as 'scotching'.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2:
== Preparation and serving ==
Scotch eggs are prepared by hard- or soft-boiling an egg, wrapping it in sausage meat, and deep-frying it.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: It is often eaten in pubs or as a cold snack at picnics.In the Netherlands and Belgium, Scotch eggs may also be called vogelnestje ("little bird's nest"), because they contain an egg.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: One 1880s Scottish recipe also calls them birds' nests.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2:
== Regional variation ==
The Manchester egg consists of a pickled egg wrapped in a mixture of pork meat and Lancashire black pudding.Vegetarian versions have also been made.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: In 2022, Guinness World Records certified a 18.341 kilograms (40.43 lb) vegetarian scotch egg as the world's largest.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: It used an ostrich egg in the center, with a coating made of peas and cheddar cheese.

Sentence 1: Schottische Eier (scotch eggs) sind eine Snack-Spezialität aus der britischen Küche.
Sentence 2: The Harwood Arms, a Michelin-starred restaurant in London, started selling a vegetarian scotch egg that uses a plant-based meat alternative in 2020, and the next year, the supermarket chain Tesco started selling a vegan version.

Sentence 2:
== Nutrition ==
A fatty food, a typical sausage-coated Scotch egg has about 200 mg dietary cholesterol per 100 grams.

Sentence 1: According to the Oxford Companion to Food, food historian Annette Hope speculated in 1987 that the inspiration may have been Indian koftas such as the Mughlai dish called nargisi kofta ("Narcissus meatballs"), in which a boiled egg is encased in a seasoned ground-meat mixture and then fried.Other claims include the item having been invented at Fortnums.

Sentence 1: El Huevo a la escocesa (en inglés: Scotch egg) consiste en un plato en el que se sirve frío un huevo duro al que se le ha quitado la cáscara y se le ha recubierto en una mezcla de salchichas picadas finamente, recubierto de pan rallado, y puesto a freír.
Sentence 2: Le scotch egg (« œuf à l'écossaise ») est un plat britannique, composé d'un œuf dur au cœur d'une boule de garniture de chair à saucisse, panée et frite.

Sentence 2: On le mange, chaud ou froid, notamment au cours d'un pique-nique.
